New MSE policy which replaces previous food safety documents at Broomfield Hospital: 08023 Food hygiene policy; Southend Hospital: HS38 Policy for food safety.

data.text: Contents
Introduction

It is the responsibility of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust to provide safe and wholesome meals through catering provisions service to its patients, staff and visitor's. The Trust is fully committed to ensuring health and safety requirements are met and the Health & Social Care Act 2008 (amended 2015), Care Quality Commission, NHS England and Improvement registration requirements are complied with in relation to catering services.
Health and Social Care Act 2008 (amended 2015) requires all NHS organisations to have policies, procedures and protocols which minimise the risk of healthcare associated infection.

The Catering department has a commitment to identify the potential food hazards within their operation and implement effective control and monitoring procedures at those points critical to food safety. The department operates a food safety management system, including full Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) and documentation for managing food safety.

All food preparation and food handling (whether used by Facilities Staff, Service Providers, Clinical and Administrative Staff or patients) areas should be maintained to safe and hygienic standards as stipulated by current legislation.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Satisfy current legal requirements by ensuring high standards of personal and environmental hygiene are adhered to at all stages for the food service delivery and that food safety is not compromised.
Specify the precautions and controls required for safe handling storage and distribution of food by health care workers and food handlers on Trust premises.
Set out the reporting and assurance framework for compliance with current NHS directives and legislative requirements for food safety.
To involve staff at all levels to be aware and committed to safe food production, handling and storage.
Definitions

table_items.text: Any staff member that is associated with the preparation or serving of food. Any person including health care workers, students, patients, visitors, contractors, outside vendors and suppliers, and voluntary workers who handle, transport or serve food on Trust premises. Catering staff refers to staff that are specifically employed by the catering department.

Any substance or product (wrapped or unwrapped) intended to be ingested. This includes food ingredients, drinks, water, baby formula, ice or any substance incorporated into the food during its preparation or treatment.
The person(s) responsible for ensuring that the requirements of food law are met.

All areas of food storage and preparation- this includes ward kitchens, zonal kitchens, commercial kitchens (for public and staff canteens), infant milk kitchens, staff kitchens, and beverage rooms. Fridges are in relative rooms, such as in Oncology and on Children's wards are also subjected to this policy.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities:
The Health and Safety Committee have the responsibility for receiving audit reports and monitoring compliance with this policy.

The Infection Prevention and Control Team (IPCT) are responsible for providing input into Estates and Facilities Management (EFM) projects and schemes that this policy applies and to identify compliant solutions. The IPCT liaise with the EFM teams to ensure appropriate action is taken internally and externally by consultants and food service providers commissioned, contracted and controlled by the organisation as required by Health & Social Care Act 2008 (amended 2015) to thereby reduce any risk of cross infection. IPCT will handle any investigation into allegations of food poisoning arising from food/drink provided on Trust premises in conjunction with EFM services, Local Authority Environmental Health department and Public Health England.

Nutrition Steering Group have responsibility to ensure that processes, training and systems are in place throughout the organisation which ensure that patients are offered statutory number of meals and drinks whilst being an inpatient.
Individual responsibilities:

The Chief Executive has the overall responsibility for the food standards within the Trust and for ensuring that a compliant catering service is provided to patients, staff and visitors in accordance with Department of Health guidelines and food safety legislation. The Chief Executive is also responsible for ensuring the trust has a nominated Food Safety Specialists; a named member of the Executive Board responsible for representing the Trust food and nutrition services.
The Director of Infection Prevention and Control has delegated executive responsibility for ensuring this policy is implemented and reviewed.

The Chief Estates and Facilities Officer is responsible for ensuring the delivery of safe and appropriate catering services within Trust premises that meets all NHS directives and legislative requirements including compliance with the Food Safety Act and local Environmental Health Officer guidance.

The Estates and Facilities Site Manager is delegated responsible for procurement, operational delivery and monitoring of catering services and retail units within current food safety management control systems and food hygiene legislation and regulations. This includes ensuring that servicing and repairing relevant assets and premises by Trust are undertaken in accordance with service provider contract or lease agreements to remedy defects that may impact on food safety standards.

The Trust EFM Contracts Manager is responsible for monitoring catering contracts and services to ensure that all aspects of the key performance indicators are met and for ensuring food safety audits are undertaken in food premises. The Trust EFM Contracts Manager is also responsible for liaison with IPCT regarding food hygiene reports and issues.

The Catering Manager is responsible for ensuring that the day to day operational running of the catering service within the Trust, in line with specified requirements and quality standards and for ensuring this policy and all current food safety legislation is adhered to. This includes maintaining an effective and well documented Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP) food safety management system which is available for inspection at all times and providing copies to Trust of all correspondence with the local authority Environmental Health Officer. The Catering Manager is also for ensuring their staff are trained and supervised in safe operating procedures that comply with food hygiene legislation, this policy and good practice in the service of food to patients, staff and visitors.

External Contractors providing patient, staff, visitor and retail catering on Trust premises are responsible for the delivery of services in accordance with specified contractual and lease agreements as well as compliance with this policy and all relevant food safety legislation. All other contractors should receive site induction packs including information on Trust policies and procedures on control of infection and IPCT should be involved in the induction process. On site charity fundraisers providing /selling food at an ad hoc event are required to follow best practice food safety as directed by the Food Standards Agency including temperature controls and basic food hygiene through a nominated lead for the event.

Ward Managers/Ward Sisters are responsible for the effective management of food hygiene within their ward /department by ensuring health care worker compliance with this policy and facilitating completion of food safety awareness training as appropriate to their role. They have specific responsibility for ensuring that food brought in by inpatients/day patients and their relatives is managed in accordance with this policy and for safe storage of food in staff rooms. It is also the responsibility of the Ward Managers/Ward Sisters to ensure that catering and beverage services outside of catering service hours are prepared and served by the ward staff.

The Catering Assistants are responsible for ensuring that food hygiene legislation and good practice is adhered to in the service of food to patients, staff and visitors. Ward caterers have day to day responsibility for overall operation and cleanliness of the ward kitchen. They are the main food handlers, preparing and serving patient meals, snacks, replenish water jugs, washing up etc.

All Food Handlers, including volunteers and designated ward staff are responsible for having an understanding of food hygiene requirements and adhering to the food safety standards in this policy as appropriate to their role. This includes training in effective hand washing and cleaning before and after handling all food and drinks. Staff must be aware of the importance of reporting any food safety breaches or near misses to the person in charge or the incident reporting system.
Food poisoning and food borne disease
Food Safety management is of paramount importance in order to prevent food poisoning and food borne disease.
Food poisoning is an unpleasant illness which usually occurs within 1 to 36 hours of eating contaminated or poisonous food. Food poisoning is caused by:
Bacteria or their toxins;
Viruses;
Chemicals such as insecticides weed killers, and cleaning products;
Metals such as lead, copper or mercury;
Poisonous Plants e.g. deadly night shade, toadstools and leaves bacterial food poisoning is by far the commonest.
Kitchen safety

Ward Kitchens are to be used by authorised staff only for health and safety and food safety reasons. Patients and visitors must not use these kitchens for the preparation of food or drink. Kitchen doors should be closed when room is not in use, and where possible they should be locked out of hours.
All food and drink products stored in ward kitchen are strictly for patients use only.
Food brought in by staff should not be stored in ward kitchen with food and drink supplies designated for patients due to risk of cross contamination.
Personal crockery, such as mugs, water bottles or any other staff personal items e.g. packed lunch, drinks, and bags should not be kept in ward kitchens.
Food spillages must be cleaned up immediately with a green disposable cloth/ green handled mop according to the surface.
Ice making machines carry high risk of cross contamination and must not be located in ward kitchens.

Fresh food must be bought, transported, date labelled, refrigerated, cooked and served on the same day. Any raw food items e.g. bacon, eggs must be covered and stored on refrigerator shelf below ready to eat foods. The food prepared must only be eaten by the intended patient. Raw foods are not permitted in ward/zonal kitchens. If fresh food is being used as part of rehabilitation, patients must be supervised by staff whom hold the relevant hygiene and food safety training.
Contractor kitchens

Services located on the hospital sites providing food, such as child care/nursery facilities, must be registered as a food service provider with the local authority Environmental Health Department and have its own approved Food and Hygiene Policy and Procedure and food safety training provision.
Infant milk kitchens

The Trust clinical guidance and operational procedures for infant milk kitchens covering formula feeds and mothers' milk apply but must be consistent with this policy. Designated milk kitchen refrigerated and freezer storage must be controlled in line  with  this  guidance  with  the  exception  of  temperature  checks  which are required to be recorded once daily on the Trust Fridge and Freezer Temperature chart.
Catering staff and food handlers
Everyone who handles food or manages food handlers as part of his or her work has a legal responsibility to safeguard food.

All catering staff must have a health check via the Occupational Health Service. This applies to food service providers, contractor staff, health care and voluntary workers. All new starters should be trained to the Basic Food Hygiene standard and immediately informed of the Trust's Food Hygiene Policy (this must be signed for). It is not necessary for retail staff to have a health check via the Occupational Health Service.

New staff must also be informed that should they suffer from diarrhoea vomiting, throat infections, skin rash, boils or other skin lesions they should report to their line manager, or the Occupational Health Nurse in accordance with infection prevention and control policy so that recognised procedures may be followed.
Personal hygiene

Food handlers and catering staff must observe high standards of personal cleanliness and have a moral and legal obligation to do so in accordance with The National Health Service (NHS), the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health (CIEH) and the Industry Guide to good practice (IG).

Uniform, including footwear, must be fit for purpose and clean, and be in accordance with Trust uniform policy. The Catering Department ensure staff are provided with sufficient uniform to ensure clean clothing is worn daily.

All catering staff must wear PPE such as disposable aprons and gloves within kitchen areas. Heat resistant gloves are not required to be worn unless required for handling hot equipment. Protective clothing, e.g. chef whites and overalls, must be worn at work and must be kept clean and smart, and changed at regular intervals.

Staff working in areas where open food is being prepared must wear a head covering that reduces the risk of hairs falling into food. Long hair must be properly tied back, without any trailing ends and fully contained in an approved hair covering.

Food handlers must not wear jewellery other than un-jewelled wedding rings and plain sleeper earrings (1cm diameter). Nail varnish and false nails must not be worn. Nails are to be kept short and scrupulously clean.
Cuts and abrasions must be covered by blue waterproof dressings.
Regular hand washing is essential and is to be carried out in designated wash hand basins only, which are provided with hot water, soap and disposable towel in accordance with hand hygiene policy.
Meal service delivery

The main objectives of hospital food delivery to patients is to ensure that patients receive food which is fresh, supplied at the correct temperature, is safe to eat, nutritious and palatable. In order for this to happen the Trust supplies complete meals to patients which are nutritionally balanced to encourage recovery. The patient can choose from a full colour menu of hot meals, finger foods, salads and sandwiches including options that are suitable for vegetarian, halal, kosher, Asian, Afro-Caribbean and special/therapeutic and modified texture dishes.
Patients have accessible allergen information provided though the printed menus. Gluten free meal choices are identified by nutritional symbol (GF) on the main menu.

It is important that the patient board above the bed is updated by the ward staff with instruction relating to catering needs. The Catering staff must not update the patient board under any circumstances. The catering staff must check with ward staff before offering food and/or beverages to the patient if the instruction is unclear, as the patient may be on a restricted/nil by mouth diet.
Provision of therapeutic and special diets

Therapeutic and special dietary meals and beverages are provided to patients as requested by patients or following a referral by ward staff to dietitians. Modified textured diets and drinks are recommended by speech and language therapists, and as instructed on the patient bedside board which must be complied with at all times to prevent risk to patient safety in line with the Oral Diets/Dysphagia Policy.

The catering department will supply a range of modified meals and special diets. Thickened and meal supplements drinks are prepared and served by ward staff. The modified texture meals comply with International Dysphagia Diet Standardisation Initiative (IDDSI) definitions for texture modified foods and thickened liquids required for individuals with dysphagia in all cultures. Levels are identified by numbers, text labels and colour codes.

It is the responsibility of the ward staff to prepare thickened liquids for patient consumption. Catering staff must not prepare or serve any thickened liquids to patients, as this requires specific training completed by the ward staff.
Food allergens

It is especially important to following the food safety instructions and training on storage, hygiene, handling, cooking of food and cleaning/disinfection detailed in this policy to minimise the risk of allergen contamination.

A patient's allergy, including food allergy, is identified by ensuring a patient wears a red wrist band following admission and the food allergy is recorded by ward staff on patient's bedside white board.
Ward staff and volunteers including feeding buddies need appropriate food allergen training proportional to their duties.

The EU Food Information for Consumers Regulations and Natasha's Law (October 2021) will require food businesses, including hospitals to provide full ingredient lists and allergen labelling on any food or drinks served or sold to patients, staff and visitors on site. The Trust's Catering and Retail Service partners provide information to patients, staff and visitors about the presence or use in their products of any of the specified allergens. This information is available in bold text in the ingredient listing on the packaging of pre-packed items.

For freshly produced items in the various menus, nutritional and allergen breakdown analysis should be provided by the catering management in hard copy format, or obtained by the ward staff by contacting the catering department directly.

Patients especially those with complex allergies may ask for food to be brought in from home or from external food suppliers. The Trust food safety disclaimer (appendix 1) must be completed if the patient requests food to be brought in from home. The Trust is not responsible for food brought in from home as it is not possible to control preparation and storage prior to being served to the patient.

If the food allergy reaction is so severe or has the potential to be so severe e.g. airborne contamination, the control measures would need to be instigated by the Trust after risk assessment at pre-assessment or on admission e.g. care for patient in a side room.

However it is not feasible to guarantee any food item provided and served in the ward kitchen is 100% free from slight cross contamination as we are not operating from a sterile or restricted environment.
Patients' own food

Patients in hospital are offered a menu that, with sensible choices, offers a well- balanced, nourishing diet. It is recognised that some visitors will bring food into hospital for patient consumption, and the Trust would not want to prevent them from doing this, providing that there are no clinical contradictions of known food allergies. However, it should be made known that the hospital cannot take responsibility for this food as it is not possible to control preparation, allergen content, preparation and storage prior to being served to the patient.
If there is an on-going issue in regards to the meal choices, the Catering Manager should be contacted to discuss menu options with the patient.

Patients and visitors must be strongly discouraged from bringing in high risk foods such as, sandwiches, cooked meats, fish product and rice, soft cheeses, eggs, takeaway foods or pre-cooked meals to reduce the risk of the growth of micro- organisms that may constitute a serious risk to health.
Cooked food brought into the Trust for patient consumption should be given to the patient by the visitor. Any foods that are not consumed should be disposed of or taken away by the visitor.
Patient brought in food must not be placed in the patient catering ward kitchen refrigerator or ward fridge unless agreed in exceptional circumstances by the nurse in charge who will ensure:
The item is in a suitable container (if not a proprietary pre-packaged item) to maintain the food temperature.

It is labelled using trust patient food labels stating patient's name, date received and use by date. If there is no use by date e.g. home prepared food, staff should record a use by date of 24 hours after receipt.
Disposal of item by ward staff after use by date and notification to patient.

If asked to reheat a food item brought in for a patient, the Trust food safety disclaimer form (appendix 1) must be completed to this effect. The nurse in charge will ensure the form is completed before the named nurse reheats the item to a temperature of at least 75º C using a standard microwave without pre-programmed settings to avoid any cross contamination. The disclaimer form to be retained with the patient's notes.
Temperature control

It is a legal requirement that temperature checks are completed throughout the entire food chain (from delivery to consumption). These temperatures will vary from the point of delivery through to storage, during preparation, cooking and service and where applicable cooling and reheating of foods.

Faulty  food  refrigeration  equipment  should be  clearly labelled  and  reported  for repair after informing the nurse in charge that the temperature cannot be maintained at a safe level or that the appliance is damaged.

For practical reasons, high risk food may occasionally need to be kept outside of the temperature limits shown above, e.g. during food preparation, but these periods must be kept as short as possible.
Kitchen fridge/freezer temperature monitoring and recording
In order to ensure food safety, it is essential to check the temperature of all refrigerators and freezers on a daily basis.

Written records of these temperatures must be made and retained for a minimum of three months by the Catering Manager. Faults should be reported to the Catering Manager. A calibrated probe thermometer should be used to check the temperature of refrigerators and chilled display units using a temperature monitoring sample.

The accuracy of all food thermometers should be checked monthly. If the calibration check indicates a faulty instrument then the probe should be returned to the catering office for repair. The results of the monthly self-calibration checks should be recorded for each probe in use.
Storage of food

Correct storage of food is fundamental to the hygienic operation of food safety. Failure to ensure satisfactory conditions of cleanliness, temperatures and stock rotation can result in problems of unfit or spoiled food. This includes mould, discolouration, staleness and insect and rodent infestation.

Food must be stored in designated food storage cupboards in sealable, clean, pest proof containers away from walls and pipes affected by condensation and off the floor and used under strict stock rotation. Food transferred to containers must be labelled with relevant use by dates in line with manufacturer's recommendations and the date that it was decanted on.
Preserves and sauces are to be individual portions and when transferred into containers or serving dishes these are to be labelled with the relevant use by date if the item is not dated individually.

Pharmacy food supplements can be stored on the top shelf of the ward kitchen patient catering refrigerator if no other ward refrigerator storage is available and subject to space availability. However items must be checked and managed by nursing staff ensuring disposal of product if it exceeds use by date.
Staff food must not be kept in ward kitchen refrigerators. The ward management are responsible for providing appropriate storage of staff food.

Refrigerators should be fully cleaned weekly removing contents, and check cleaned daily by ward / departmental staff following the cleaning procedures as outlined in the food safety procedure document.
Product date codes
To ensure good stock rotation and compliance with the Food Labelling Regulations, all foods must be date coded.
Date codes are classified under two headings:
“Use by” – applied to highly perishable “high risk” products such as cooked meats, dairy products
“Best before” – applied to perishable and non-perishable foods, e.g. cereals and packed products, cans, usually with a shelf life of over three months.

All products must be used before the expiry of these dates and care must be taken when using products to check labelling instructions, which may indicate ‘refrigerate after opening' and/or ‘use within three days of opening'.
Opened packs of food should be decanted into clean containers with close fitting lids labelled and date coded in accordance with the manufactures recommendations.
Preparation of food

The preparation of all foods including microwavable meals and raw food, such as raw meat, fish, and vegetables must be carried out in a specific area, away from surfaces where cooked and ready to eat foods is prepared. It is essential that preparation surfaces, sinks and utensils be thoroughly cleaned and sanitised between each food preparation task in line with food safety procedures.
The process for preparation of chilled cooked foods and frozen cooked foods is outlined in the food safety procedure document.
Cleaning and sanitising

It is a legal requirement that all parts of food premises are kept clean. A specific cleaning schedule must be completed to help maintain a high standard of cleanliness and food safety. It must be split into daily, weekly and monthly tasks and comply with the National Standards of Cleanliness.
Catering folder

The Catering folder should be held in all kitchens and provide information on, but not limited to; patient menus, nutritional and allergen details, special menus, microwave cooking times, and meal temperature probes sheets.

In addition included in the folder are the blank refrigeration temperature recording forms, cleaning schedules, ward equipment check lists, COSHH information and a copy of the Trust food hygiene policy and hand hygiene/infection prevention policy.
Food waste and disposal
Food items that have gone out of date should be recorded by the ward catering staff for collation and reporting by the Catering Manager.
Suitable receptacles should be provided, both inside and outside clinical areas for the disposal of waste food and debris.

Food waste and other refuse must not accumulate in kitchens and should not be left overnight. Waste bins and sacks must be regularly emptied throughout the day. Internal refuse containers should be maintained in good condition and be regularly cleaned and disinfected in accordance with the Trust waste management policy and cleaning policy.
Waste oil should be removed by an approved contractor and appropriate paper work kept on file in accordance with the Trust waste management policy.
Food pests and pest control
Kitchen areas can provide ideal conditions for the survival and multiplication of pests which can spoil and contaminate food, and thereby transmit infectious diseases.

Major pest problems will be undertaken either by Trust's pest control service provider or by local authority as outlined in the document ‘Food Hygiene and Pest Control in the Health service HC (86)14'
Only using approved COSHH assessed products in kitchens is permitted. Fly spray, poisons and other chemicals must not be used in kitchens.
The strategies that must be in place to prevent kitchen pests are:
Ensuring cleaning schedules are properly carried out
Inspecting dry goods regularly for signs of infestation
Reporting all pest sightings
Removing refuse and food waste from the kitchen as soon as possible
Reporting any defects in the building fabric that could be conducive to infestation.
Environmental Health Officer (EHO) visits

The Environmental Health Officer (EHO) is a local authority official responsible for the enforcement of legislation relating to food hygiene and food safety. The functions of an EHO in the field of food hygiene can be summarised as follows:
To ensure product safety and fitness for consumption
To reduce possible sources of contamination entering the food environment
To monitor conditions and hygienic operation within the food environment
To ensure compliance with relevant legislation
To establish the integrity of management and effectiveness of control procedures
To offer professional advice

Hygiene offences can be the subject of a prosecution or the issue of an improvement notice allowing not less than  days to comply. Where there is an imminent risk of injury to health, an emergency prohibition notice can be served requiring the immediate cessation of a process or use of equipment, or closure of the premises; food which is regarded as unfit for consumption or is contaminated can be seized. However, most EHO's prefer, in the first instance, to act by means of a letter specifying items to be remedied within a stated time, provided they are confident the work will be carried out.
Following the EHO visit, the Catering Manager is to provide the Estates and Facilities Site Manager with an overview of findings and action plans for rectifications.
Catering monitoring
Ward kitchens are audited for food safety and cleanliness on a regular basis in accordance with the monitoring schedule.
The main kitchen is formally audited on an annual basis by the EHO and monthly Catering Team Leader.
Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) review takes place by the EFM Quality Assurance Team on an annual basis or when there has been an alteration
in the kitchen area. Six monthly reviews take place of this documentation by the Catering Management team.
In the event of food poisoning being suspected, a formal incident report form should be completed.
Training requirements

Outline training requirements or if not appropriate state: All catering staff, including contracted staff, should be trained to the Basic Food Hygiene standard and immediately informed of the Trust's Food Hygiene Policy.
Training will include:
Practical on the job training by a competent Supervisor/Manager/Trainer
Theoretical training as part of structured food hygiene training- “Working Safely With Food” level 2 training and “Know your allergens” in line with Food Information Regulations
Product specific task training e.g. use of a particular cleaning product of specialised cleaning equipment
Specific task training e.g. cleaning dangerous machinery such as meat slicers
Chemical safety and Cleaning training
Use and care of protective equipment
All Therapists overseeing food preparation as part of patient rehabilitation must all be trained to the Basic Food Hygiene standard.

The catering and retail contract employees in the leased units and any other external catering providers (including charitable organisations) are also required to undertake food handling training and appropriate training on food safety management system based on HACCP principles as specified by food safety legislation and Trust service agreements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Business Development Unit, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policy and procedural guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Business Development Unit of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)

International Dysphagia Diet Standardisation Initiative (IDDSI) https://iddsi.org/framework/

Natasha's Law (October 2021) https://www.gov.uk/government/news/natashas-legacy-becomes-law
Appendix 1: Food safety disclaimer form
Please note that the Trust operates within the confines of both The Food Hygiene (England) regulations 2006 and the Trusts Food Safety Policy.
Patients in hospital are offered a well-balanced, nourishing diet. However it is recognised that patients may ask for food from home, or visitors might bring in gifts of snacks or drinks.

If the patient (adult/child) eats food in the high risk category listed below that is given to them other than by the hospital caterer or ward staff they do so at their own risk. This includes allergen free meals and any items that ward staff are asked to reheat in a microwave.
High risk foods for which the Trust cannot accept responsibility for if the patient consumes them include, but is not limited to:
Take away foods
Cooked meats
Shell eggs,
Sandwiches,
Cooked rice,
Fish paste,
Fresh or synthetic cream e.g. trifles, cream cakes.

The Trust does not accept responsibility for food or beverages retained by patients from any source other than from authorised hospital catering. Any items stored in the ward fridge will be labelled with patient's name, date of receipt and use by date and disposed of after use by date. Patients consume these items at their own risk and the Trust will not be liable for any personal injury arising as a result. This does not affect the patient's statutory rights.
I confirm that I have been made aware of the risks associated with providing or eating food from other sources for consumption and accept that the Trust take no responsibility for this action.

PATIENT NAME:………………………………………………………………………………… SIGNATURE OF PATIENT/CARER :……………………PRINTED NAME ………………… WITNESSED BY WARD STAFF/NURSE………………………………………………………… PRINTED NAME:………………………………………… DESIGNATION…………………. DATE……………………………………………..
If patient refuses to sign disclaimer form, print patients name and obtain confirmatory signature of a second member of staff as a witness.
Patient / carer refused to sign disclaimer form:
WITNESSED BY WARD STAFF/NURSE………………………………………………………… PRINTED NAME:………………………………………… DESIGNATION…………………. DATE……………………………………………..
Completed form to be filed in patient's health records by nursing staff.
Appendix 2: Food safety disclaimer poster - relatives room
FOOD SAFETY DISCLAIMER RELATIVES AND VISITORS ROOM
The Trust does not accept responsibility for food or beverages brought in by family and friends for their own consumption.
Family and Friends consume items they have stored, prepared and cooked for themselves at their own risk.
Trust will not be liable for any personal injury arising as a result. This does not affect your statutory rights.

Please note that any items stored in the relatives and visitor room fridge must be labelled by the relative/visitor with name, date of receipt and use by date and will be disposed of after use by date.
MSE NHS Foundation Trust operates within the confines of The Food Hygiene (England) regulations  and the Trust Policy for Food Safety.

table_items.text: ☐ A change in a service to patients
☒ A change to an existing document
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Who benefits from this change and how?
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No; the policy ensures compliance with food safety regulations
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
Yes- standardised consultation- see consulted with
